structured_info.title_cn: 混合交通流中连接自动驾驶车辆专用车道的基本图建模
structured_info.title_en: Modeling the Fundamental Diagram of Mixed Traffic Flow With Dedicated Lanes for Connected Automated Vehicles
structured_info.abstract: To solve the problems of when to set up connected automated vehicles (CAVs) dedicated lanes and how many CAVs dedicated lanes to set up under different penetration rates of CAVs, this work focuses on modeling the fundamental diagram of mixed traffic flow with dedicated lanes for CAVs. Firstly, the car-following modes and their proportion of mixed traffic flow without and with CAVs dedicated lanes are analyzed. Secondly, the fundamental diagram of mixed traffic flow is derived based on car-following models to analyze the traffic capacity with and without CAVs dedicated lanes. Then, the relevant properties of the fundamental diagram with CAVs dedicated lanes are proposed and proved. Finally, the sensitivity of related parameters (e.g., CAVs penetration rate, time headway, and free-flow speed) in the fundamental diagram is discussed. Results show that (1) the increase of CAVs penetration rate and free-flow speed can improve the traffic capacity; (2) the design of smaller CAVs time headway benefits traffic capacity. Moreover, one and two CAVs dedicated lanes of three manual lanes are set to improve the traffic capacity to the greatest extent when the penetration rate of CAVs reaches 0.6 and 0.86, respectively. It is noteworthy that developing CAVs dedicated lanes under a reasonable CAVs penetration rate does not waste resources and increases traffic congestion while improving traffic capacity.
structured_info.methodology: The study analyzes car-following modes in mixed traffic flow, derives the fundamental diagram model based on car-following models, and evaluates the impact of CAVs dedicated lanes on traffic capacity under different penetration rates of CAVs. Theoretical analysis and simulation experiments in SUMO are used to verify the model.
structured_info.conclusion: The study concludes that (1) traffic capacity and critical traffic density increase with CAVs penetration rates; (2) smaller CAVs time headway improves traffic capacity; (3) setting one and two CAVs dedicated lanes maximizes traffic capacity at penetration rates of 0.6 and 0.86, respectively. The findings provide insights for optimizing CAVs dedicated lane deployment.
structured_info.venue: IEEE Transactions on Intelligent Transportation Systems

analysis.Overview: The paper proposes a fundamental diagram model for mixed traffic flow with dedicated lanes for connected automated vehicles (CAVs). It analyzes car-following modes, derives the fundamental diagram, and evaluates the impact of CAVs dedicated lanes on traffic capacity under different penetration rates.
Background_and_Motivation: The study addresses the challenge of optimizing the deployment of CAVs dedicated lanes to improve traffic efficiency and safety.
The research aims to solve when and how many CAVs dedicated lanes should be set up under different penetration rates of CAVs.
The authors argue that setting dedicated lanes for CAVs can avoid mixed traffic scenarios, which are challenging due to unpredictable human-driven vehicle behavior.
The problem is linked to broader challenges in traffic flow management and the integration of CAVs into existing transportation systems.
The paper contributes to transportation engineering, traffic flow theory, and intelligent transportation systems.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Core concepts include car-following modes (C-H, C-C, H-C, H-H), fundamental diagram, and traffic capacity.
The logical relationship involves deriving the fundamental diagram from car-following models and analyzing the impact of dedicated lanes.
Key assumptions include steady-state traffic flow and negligible vehicle maneuverability variation.
The paper contributes a theoretical framework for modeling mixed traffic flow with CAVs dedicated lanes and provides insights for practical deployment.
Methodology: The study uses car-following models to derive the fundamental diagram and analyzes traffic capacity with and without dedicated lanes.
The methodology is novel in integrating dedicated lanes into the fundamental diagram model and is applicable to various traffic scenarios.
Data sources include theoretical models and simulation experiments in SUMO, with parameters like time headway and free-flow speed varied.
Experimental design includes sensitivity analysis of key parameters, and evaluation metrics focus on traffic capacity and critical density.
The research follows a theoretical paradigm in traffic flow modeling, influencing the analytical approach.
Results: Key results show that traffic capacity increases with CAVs penetration rate and free-flow speed, and decreases with larger time headway.
The results are reliable as they are validated through simulation and theoretical analysis, showing consistent trends.
Argumentation_and_Logic: The authors structure their argument by first analyzing car-following modes, then deriving the fundamental diagram, and finally evaluating the impact of dedicated lanes.
Key steps include modeling car-following modes, deriving the fundamental diagram, and proving related properties.
Strengths include comprehensive analysis and validation; weaknesses may include simplifying assumptions like steady-state traffic flow.
Strengths_and_Limitations: Strengths include a novel framework for modeling CAVs dedicated lanes and practical insights for deployment.
Limitations include assumptions like steady-state traffic flow and negligible vehicle maneuverability variation.
The theoretical paradigm constrains conclusions to idealized traffic conditions.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: The paper contributes to the discourse on CAVs integration into traffic systems by providing a theoretical foundation.
The authors use technical terminology and a formal tone, building authority through citations and rigorous analysis.
Citations are used to establish context and justify assumptions, with motivations rooted in improving traffic efficiency and safety.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Main conclusions highlight the benefits of CAVs dedicated lanes under optimal penetration rates and parameter settings.
Future research directions include experimental validation, different management strategies, and network-level impacts of dedicated lanes.
